facts.text: Civil Appeals No. 522 and 523 of 1962 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 30, 1960 of the Kerala High Court in A. S. No. 233 of 1959 and O.P. No. 19 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals No. 522 and 523 of 1962. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated November 30, 1960 of the Kerala High Court in A. S. No. 233 of 1959 and O.P. No. 19 of 1952.

facts.text: Respondent is a firm carrying on business at Ernakulam as Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories manufacturing medicinal products.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, as stated already, is a firm and it carries on business at Ernakulam in the same name and style as the Trade Mark number in companytroversy--Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories.

facts.text: Business of respondent firm founded in 1926 by Dr. Sarvothama Rao.

anchor.surface_text: The business of the firm was founded sometime in 1926 by one Dr. Sarvothama Rao who is number numbermore.

facts.text: Respondent changed name from Navaratna Pharmacy to Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories in January 1945.

anchor.surface_text: When started, the business was called Navaratna Pharmacy but from January, 1945 the name of the business was changed to the present one Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories.

facts.text: Respondent used Trade Mark Navaratna on products from the beginning.

anchor.surface_text: From the very beginning the proprietors used the Trade, Mark Navaratna on the products which they manufactured and sold.

facts.text: In December 1928, word Navaratna and Navaratna Pharmacy registered by declaration before Registrar of Assurances, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: In December, 1928 the word Navaratna and the name Navaratna Pharmacy as companynoting the products of the respondent firm were registered by a declaration of ownership before the Registrar of Assurances, Calcutta.

facts.text: Respondent registered Navarama as Trade Mark under Cochin Trade Marks Act on January 31, 1947 for medicinal preparations.

anchor.surface_text: Vide the Cochin Trade Marks Act 19 of 1199  1944  the respondent-firm registered the word Navarama as a Trade Mark in respect of its medicinal preparations, on January 31, 1947

facts.text: Respondent registered Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories as Trade Mark on February 17, 1948 under Cochin Act.

anchor.surface_text: and another mark companysisting of the words Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories to denote the same products on February 17, 1948.

facts.text: Respondent firm has expanding business selling products under Navaratna and other names continuously.

anchor.surface_text: There is evidence that the respondent-firm has been having an expanding business in the products which it manufactures and has been selling the same under the above and other companynate names, and this has companytinued ever since.

facts.text: Respondent registered Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories in Bombay Trade Marks Registry via reciprocal arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: availing itself of this provision the respondent-firm applied for the registration of the words Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories in the Trade spp./65-4 Marks Registry at Bombay. The application was advertised and numberopposition having been entered, the Trade Mark was registered.

facts.text: Appellant carries on business in Ayurvedic pharmaceutical products at Jullundur under Navaratna Kalpa Pharmacy.

anchor.surface_text: Pausing here, certain facts have to be set out in relation to the appellant, since they are material for understanding the Origin Of the proceedings which have given rise to these appeals. The appellant has, for some Years Past, been carrying on business in the preparation of Ayurvedic Pharmaceutical Products at Jullundur City in East punjab under the name of the Navaratna Kalpa Pharmacy

facts.text: Appellant applied for registration of Navaratna Kalpa as Trade Mark in October 1946.

anchor.surface_text: while so, in October, 1946, The applied for the registration of the Words NaVaratna Kalpa as a Trade Mark for his medicinal preparations.

facts.text: Appellant's application for Navaratna Kalpa advertised in April 1950, opposed by respondent, registration refused as descriptive.

anchor.surface_text: This application was advertised in April, 1950, and the, respondent-firm opposed the application for registration on the ground that the word -Navaratna was descriptive and, having numberdistinctiveness, companyld number be registered. This objection prevailed and the registration was refused.

facts.text: Respondent filed Original Suit No. 233 of 1951 before District Judge Anjikaimal for permanent injunction against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent had filed wit No. 233 of 1951  from which C.A. No. 522 of 1962 arises  before the District Judge, Anjikaimal, for a permanent injunction restraining the appellant from advertising, selling or offering for sale any preparations under a trade mark companybining the word Navaratne or any similar word etc.

facts.text: Appellant filed O.P. No. 19 of 1952 in High Court of Travancore-Cochin for removal of respondent's trade marks from register.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant accordingly Mod O.P. No. 19 of 1952 in the High Court of Travancore-Cochin praying that the registration of the word Navaratna by itself or as part of other marks as a trade mark for goods belonging to the respondent be removed from the register.

facts.text: District Judge found no passing off by appellant due to packing and get-up differences.

anchor.surface_text: the learned District Judge found  1  that having regard to the method of packing adopted and theother features of the get-up etc., on which the defence had relied,the defendant was number guilty of passing off

facts.text: District Judge found Navaratna is a common word in Ayurvedic phraseology, no exclusive right to respondent.

anchor.surface_text: 2  that the word Navaratna was a companymon word in Ayurvedic phraseology and companysequently the plaintiff companyld number claim any exclusive title to the use of that word by reason of his having used it for his products even though this had been for a number of years.

facts.text: District Judge held Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories validly registered, acquired distinctiveness before February 25, 1937.

anchor.surface_text: The learned District Judge further held the mark Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories or its permissible variants had been used long before February 25, 1937 and having acquired factual distinctiveness, was registerable under the proviso to S. 6 3  of the Act.

facts.text: District Judge granted decree for injunction confined to Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff was, therefore, granted a decree for an injunction companyfined to the trade mark Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories.

facts.text: Kerala High Court confirmed District Judge's findings and decree, and order in O.P. No. 19 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: By a companymon judgment the learned Judges companyfirmed all the findings and the decree of the learned District Judge and made an order in the, Original Petition companyformably to this decision.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave for these appeals.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals have been preferred by the appellant after obtaining special leave from this Court in these two matters respectively.

issues.text: Dealing next with the question as to whether the mark Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories could be validly registered and rights claimed for such a registration

anchor.surface_text: Dealing next with the question as to whether the mark Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories could be validly registered and rights claimed for such a registration, the learned Judge answered it in the affirmative pointing out that no evidence was placed before the Court of the use by any other person, firm or concern of that name and that there was evidence which was uncontradicted that trade name Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories or some variant of the same had been used as a trade mark by the plaintiff for a very long time and had come in the market to denote exclusively the goods of the plaintiff.

issues.text: That the word Navaratna in its etymological sense meant Ayurvedic preparations of a particular composition and that the word had been generally adopted by several firms and organisations for designating their preparations which they vended with that description. It was therefore submitted that the plaintiff could claim no exclusive title to the use of that word

anchor.surface_text: By his written statement the defendant raised principally three points 1. a That the word Navaratna in its etymo- logical sense meant Ayurvedic preparations of a particular composition and that the word had been generally adopted by several firms and organisations for designating their preparations which they vended with that description. It was therefore submitted that the plaintiff could claim no exclusive title to the use of that word which was a common word for the description of the product as a trade mark to designate its pharmaceutical preparations.

issues.text: As regards the trade mark Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories which was in fact the name in which the plaintiff carried on its business, the defence was that the crucial integer in that mark was the expression Navaratna and that if the plaintiff was not entitled to the exclusive use of the word Navaratna to designate its products, the combination of the word with the two other words Pharmaceutical and Laboratories which were ordinary English words descriptive of the place where medicines were prepared could not render the trade mark a registerable one

anchor.surface_text: 1. b As regards the trade mark Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories which was in fact the name in which the plain- tiff carried on its business, the defence was that the crucial integer in that mark was the expression Navaratna and that if the plaintiff was not entitled to the exclusive use of the word Navaratna to designate its products, the combination of the word with the two other words Pharmaceutical and Laboratories which were ordinary English words descriptive of the place where medicines were prepared could not render the trade mark a registerable one. For these two reasons the defence was that no claim could be made to relief under s. 21 of the Trade Marks Act, 1940.

issues.text: Next it was submitted that even on the basis that the plaintiff was entitled to the use of the word Navaratna either alone or in the combination Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories, still the use, of the trade mark by the defendant of the words Navaratna Kalpa and Navaratna Kalpa Pharmacy were not either identical with nor deceptively similar to the plaintiffs marks and therefore he was not guilty of any infringement

anchor.surface_text: Next it was submitted that even on the basis that the plaintiff was entitled to the use of the word Navaratna either alone or in the combination Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories, still the use, of the trade mark by the defendant of the words Navaratna Kalpa and Navaratna Kalpa Pharmacy were not either identical with nor deceptively similar to the plaintiffs marks and therefore he was not guilty of any infringement.

issues.text: As regards the claim for relief on the basis of passing off, the defendant laid stress upon the packing, get-up and the manner in which the trade origin of the goods was clearly brought out in the packages in which his preparations were marketed and it was submitted that they clearly negatived any possibility of passing off

holdings.text: The respondent's trade mark Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories was validly registered under the proviso to s.6(3) of the Trade Marks Act, 1940 notwithstanding its descriptiveness, due to continuous use from before February 25, 1937 and acquired distinctiveness by user.

anchor.surface_text: From this it would follow that the respondents mark was rightly registered and that he was entitled to protect an invasion of his right by seeking a perpetual injunction from persons who invaded those rights. The next part of the learned Counsels argument related to the question whether the Trade Mark used by the appella

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent factual findings of long user (from 1926) acquiring distinctiveness affirmed; proviso to s.6(3) interpreted to lift s.6(1)(d) bar for old descriptive marks upon proof of factual distinctiveness; rejects narrow construction rendering proviso otiose; distinguishes precedents like Yorkshire Copper.

holdings.text: Appellant's marks Navaratna Pharmacy and Navaratna Kalpa are deceptively similar to respondent's registered mark Navaratna Pharmaceutical Laboratories so as to constitute infringement under s.21 of the Trade Marks Act, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the conclusion reached by the Courts below that the appellants mark is deceptively similar to that of the respondents cannot be stated to be erroneous. Besides, this question of deceptive similarity is a question of fact, unless the test employed for determining it suffers from error.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of lower courts upheld as reasonable; deceptive similarity assessed by comparing marks as wholes (visual/phonetic/basic idea/essential features) for average purchaser; no error in test applied.

holdings.text: Action for infringement of registered trade mark under s.21 is distinct from passing off; differences in get-up, packing and labelling are irrelevant to statutory infringement which focuses on similarity of marks themselves.

anchor.surface_text: These matters which are of the essence of the cause of action for relief on the ground of passing off play but a limited role in an action for infringement of a registered trade mark by the registered proprietor who has a statutory right to that mark and who has a statutory remedy in the event of the use by another of that mark or a colourable imitation thereof.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory right vindicates exclusive use of registered mark; requires only likelihood of deception from mark similarity in course of trade; passing off requires proof of misrepresentation via get-up leading to actual confusion; essential features adoption suffices for infringement without further evidence.

holdings.text: Disclaimer of exclusive right to Navaratna under s.13 not ordered as no prayer made in rectification petition under s.46(2) nor raised before High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Under the terms of s. 13 of the Act, an order directing disclaimer could have been passed only by the High Court when dealing with the appellants application under s. 46 (2) of the Act. The application that he filed contained no prayer to direct a disclaimer, and no submission appears to have been made to the High Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural: point not raised in pleadings or submissions below; improper to entertain first time in Supreme Court.

holdings.text: Defence of honest concurrent user under s.10(2) not available as not raised in courts below.

anchor.surface_text: Lastly it was submitted that this was a case of honest concurrent user within s. 10 (2) of the Act. This point was, however, not raised in any of the Courts below and we do not propose to entertain it for the first time in this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural: new point not agitated below.

anchor.surface_text: As Pry L. J. said in Dunn 1 with reference to the company- responding law in U.K. which has been reproduced by s. 6 of the Indian Act It is said that the words Fruit-Salt have never been used in companylocation except by Mr. Eno. Be it so I cannot help regarding the attempt on Mr. Enos part as an instance of that perpetual struggle which it seems to me is going on to enclose and to appropriate as private property certain little strips of the great open companymon of the English language.

precedents.cited_proposition: Attempt to appropriate descriptive words like Fruit-Salt as private property is a trespass against the common of language

precedents.cited_holding: Judged by this test it could not be seriously contended that the prohibition in s.6(1)(d) would be attracted to this mark

precedents.case_name: Yorkshire Copper Works Ltd. v. Registrar of Trade Marks
precedents.cited_proposition: Distinctiveness in fact is not conclusive for registration if the mark lacks inherent adaptability to distinguish, such as geographical names
precedents.cited_holding: Even 100 per cent distinctiveness does not override lack of inherent capacity to distinguish for geographical names

precedents.citation: Ram Rekhpal v. Amrit Dhara Pharmacy 1 A.I.R. 1957 All. 683

anchor.surface_text: Before proceeding further we should, add what there is a decision of the Allahabad High Court in Ram Rekhpal v. Amrit Dhara Pharmacy 1  in which the question of the companystruction of the proviso came up for companysideration. The learned Judges, however, without any discussion of the points involved, expressed their opinion that even if the mark came within the prohibition in cl.  d  of sub-s.  1  of s. 6, an old mark i.e., marks in use from before February 25, 1937 would qualify for registration if there was evidence of factual a distinctiveness.

precedents.case_name: Ram Rekhpal v. Amrit Dhara Pharmacy
precedents.cited_proposition: Old marks prior to February 25, 1937 qualify for registration under proviso to s.6(3) even if within prohibition of cl.(d) s.6(1) upon evidence of factual distinctiveness

precedents.case_name: In the matter of India Electric Works Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Proviso to s.6(3) requires proof of acquired distinctiveness; mere user not sufficient
precedents.cited_holding: The applicant had not established factual acquired distinctiveness for the geographical word 'India'

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the conclusion reached by the Courts below that the appellants mark is deceptively similar to that of the respondents cannot be stated to be erroneous. Besides, this question of deceptive similarity is a question of fact, unless the test employed for determining it suffers from error.

It appears to us that the conclusion reached by the Courts below that the appellants mark is deceptively similar to that of the respondents cannot be stated to be erroneous. Besides, this question of deceptive similarity is a question of fact, unless the test employed for determining it suffers from error.

These matters which are of the essence of the cause of action for relief on the ground of passing off play but a limited role in an action for infringement of a registered trade mark by the registered proprietor who has a statutory right to that mark and who has a statutory remedy in the event of the use by another of that mark or a colourable imitation thereof.
